q1.label: 1. Your stage of life
q1.tooltip: How much time you have is important. The younger you are, the more time you have to ride the ups and downs in value that you could experience with some investments.
q1.question: What’s your age?

q2.label: 2. Your income
q2.tooltip: Your income level indicates how much of a cushion you might have... and how cautious you might be about losing it.
q2.question: What’s your income each year?

q3.label: 3. Your time horizon
q3.tooltip: How soon will you need the money you're investing? The longer you can leave it, the more time you have to ride the ups and downs in value that you could experience with some investments.
q3.question: How long are you investing for?

q4.label: 4. Your preparedness
q4.tooltip: Having a savings cushion also means that you can avoid suddenly cashing up your investments.
q4.question: Do you have savings you can access if you lose your day-to-day income?

options.label: Some savings or insurance that would help
options.name: q4b

options.label: Savings or insurance to cover essential costs for several months
options.name: q4c

q5.label: 5. Your need for returns
q5.tooltip: There is always a risk that your investment could lose value. How you feel about that indicates what type of investor you are, and what kinds of investments you should choose.
q5.question: What's most important to you?

options.label: Always getting back at least as much money as I put in
options.name: q5a

options.label: Coming out ahead with my investments in the end, despite ups and downs along the way
options.name: q5b

options.label: Maximum profit regardless of risk – I'm investing money I can afford to lose
options.name: q5c

q6.label: 6. Your debt
q6.tooltip: Generally, it's good to get any debt you have out of the way before you start to invest. (KiwiSaver is an exception because of the government and employer contributions.)
q6.question: How much total debt do you have? (Exclude student loans, but include mortgages.)

options.label: Debt worth more than a year's income
options.name: q6a

options.label: Debt worth less than a year's income
options.name: q6b

q7.label: 7. Your outlook
q7.tooltip: Investments go up and down in value, so how uncomfortable you might be in the event of a loss will influence what type of investor you are.
q7.question: Which description best fits you?

options.label: Cautious, but realise some risk may be necessary to make money over the long term
options.name: q7b

options.label: Comfortable in taking a risk with money
options.name: q7c

q8.label: 8. Your security
q8.tooltip: A sudden change in your income could mean that you need to get to your funds in a hurry – which means that some kinds of investments won't be a good option.
q8.question: How do you see the security of your job, business or finances over the next five years?

q9.label: 9. Your comfort with risk
q9.tooltip: The higher the risk you take, the higher the returns you could receive – but the more chance you have of taking a loss, too.
q9.question: What level of risk are you comfortable taking?
